We provide a categorical approach to the foundations of quantum theory. The approach is purely categorical and does not presuppose any analytical structure. The axioms are designed to be as simple as possible and to capture the essence of quantum theory. The axioms are shown to be sufficient to characterize the category of operators on Hilbert spaces. The axioms are then shown to be necessary by showing that they imply the standard axioms of quantum theory. The approach is illustrated by showing that the category of continuous linear operators between Hilbert spaces is equivalent to the category of operators on Hilbert spaces.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasites that cause diseases in both invertebrates and vertebrates. The evolutionary origin of this group has been elusive, and the only available phylogenetic evidence is based on a small number of species. Here, we present a comprehensive analysis of the genomes of two myxozoans and a cnidarian parasite, and we show that myxozoans are a sister group to the less reduced cnidarian parasite, P. hydriforme. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. This study provides insights into the extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic endoparasite. (Show more)

COVID-19 is a global pandemic that has caused millions of deaths worldwide. The disease is caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus, which is able to evade the antiviral action of interferon (IFN) by blocking nuclear import of signaling proteins. Here we show that the accessory protein Orf6 of SARS-CoV-2 is able to block nuclear import of STAT1 and STAT2. We found that Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex and interacts with Nup98-Rae1. We show that this interaction is required for the anti-IFN activity of Orf6. Our results unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. Our findings may lead to the development of new strategies to combat COVID-19. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of these channels. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of the proton channel. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the proton channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric proton channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the proton channel. We propose that Zn2+ binding has two major effects on the proton channel: (i) at low concentrations, Zn2+ binds to one site and prevents the opening conformational change of the pore of the proton channel, thereby inhibiting proton conduction; and (ii) at high concentrations, Zn2+, in addition, binds to a second site and inhibits the outward movement of the voltage sensor of the proton channel. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits the proton channel will further our understanding of the proton channel and might provide valuable information for future drug development for the proton channel

Climate change will affect the global food supply. We quantify the impact of global warming on maize production and yield variability in the major maize-producing and -exporting countries. We find that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields will increase almost everywhere to values much larger than present-day values. This higher CV is due both to an increase in the standard deviation of yields and a decrease in mean yields. For the top four maize-exporting countries, which account for 87% of global maize exports, the probability that they have simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year is presently virtually zero, but it increases to 7% under 2 °C warming and 86% under 4 °C warming. Our results portend rising instability in global grain trade and international grain prices, affecting especially the ∼800 million people living in extreme poverty who are most vulnerable to food price spikes. They also underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance. (Show more)

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in grasslands. However, the extent to which species partition food resources is largely unknown because of the difficulty of species-level identification of plant remains in traditional studies. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large mammals in semiarid African savanna. We found that diet composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and that dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. Such taxonomically fine-grained diet partitioning suggests that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. Our results highlight the importance of diet composition in understanding the mechanisms of coexistence in large mammal communities. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses in the United States. The survey was fielded between March 28 and April 4, 2020, just as the COVID-19 pandemic was beginning to take hold. Our findings suggest that many small businesses are already experiencing layoffs and closures. Moreover, many businesses are financially fragile. Finally, many businesses are planning to seek funding through the Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security (CARES) Act. However, many anticipate problems with accessing the program.

Plastic debris in the ocean is a major environmental concern. However, the global load of plastic debris on the open ocean surface is still unknown. We show that the global load of plastic debris on the open ocean surface is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This is due to size-selective sinks removing millimeter-sized fragments of floating plastic on a large scale. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The origin of presolar silicon carbide grains is still a matter of debate. We determined the ages of 40 large presolar silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. We found that a majority of the grains have ages of <300 Ma, which is shorter than theoretical estimates for large grains. This indicates that the grains condensed in outflows of asymptotic giant branch stars <4.9 Ga ago that possibly formed during an episode of enhanced star formation ∼7 Ga ago. A minority of the grains have ages >1 Ga, which is longer than expected for large grains. We estimate that the majority of the grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun. Our results provide constraints for the formation of presolar silicon carbide grains. They also provide evidence for a complex history of the solar system. © 2018, The Author(s).

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded substantially. The effective CPUE of most countries has decreased since 1950, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. The global fleet could increase by 1 million motorized vessels by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries. This would challenge sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to increase the number of offspring produced in a given period of time is a fundamental aspect of animal biology. Here, we show that the ability to increase the number of offspring produced in a given period of time is correlated with the practice of allonursing and domestication. These two factors increase the amount of energy available to the mother, which should increase reproductive output. We show that this is indeed the case. Our results suggest that the ultimate factor limiting reproductive output in placental mammals is maternal metabolic power rather than resource availability. This is an important finding for understanding the evolution of reproduction in mammals and other species. It also has implications for the evolution of domestication and allomaternal care. Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of alpha-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. We show here that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which was well tolerated in a 6 wk-long phase II trial in patients with epilepsy, is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. Our results suggest that VX-765, a drug that was well tolerated in a 6 wk-long phase II trial in patients with epilepsy, is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels. It is the most abundant cell type in the body and is responsible for many of the most important functions of the cardiovascular system. The endothelium is able to control many of the most important physiological processes, including blood pressure, inflammation, and blood clotting. The endothelium is able to integrate information from multiple sources and coordinate responses. Here, we show that the endothelium is a highly connected network of cells. The network is small-world, which means that it is both efficient at local and global communication. This design is effective for the control of the cardiovascular system.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been a major public health crisis. In this paper, we describe the data that we have collected and made publicly available through the COVIDcast API. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution and are updated daily. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. The data are available for use in research and decision-making.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion channels in the human body. They are involved in a wide range of physiological processes and are the target of many drugs. The selectivity filter and the activation gate are functionally and structurally coupled. We have identified a second Threonine residue within the TTVGYGD signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. We show that this residue is essential for the allosteric coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter. Our results provide a structural explanation for the lack of C-type inactivation gating in the KcsA mutant. Finally, we provide a crystallographic demonstration that closed-state inactivation can be achieved by the structural collapse of the channel’s selectivity filter. This work provides a structural explanation for the allosteric coupling between the activation gate and the selectivity filter in potassium channels. It also provides a structural explanation for the lack of C-type inactivation gating in the KcsA mutant. This work may also have implications for the design of new drugs. The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is critical for the health of the host. The role of the gut microbiome in health and disease is just beginning to be understood. The gut microbiome is also a dynamic system that is influenced by the host and the host environment. The gut microbiome is also a complex system that is difficult to study. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the natural products of anaerobic fungi, which are a group of gut fungi that have not been studied extensively. The results of this study support the hypothesis that anaerobic fungi synthesize natural products that could be used as a source of therapeutics.

Anxiety is a common feature of psychiatric disorders, and it is well known that anxiety is associated with a lower probability to become dominant in a social hierarchy. Here we show that anxiety directly influences social dominance in rats and identify a key role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. We found that high-anxious animals are prone to become subordinate during a social encounter with a low-anxious rat and exhibit reduced mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. We further show that the low probability to become dominant in high-anxious animals is reversed by microinfusion of mitochondrial inhibitors into the nucleus accumbens. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. The design of mechanical structures with desired behaviors is of great importance for various applications. However, the use of a single material phase and heuristically developed structural patterns leads to restricted design space and potential failure to achieve specific target behaviors. Here, we propose a free-form inverse design approach to synthesize multiple hyperelastic materials with distinct properties into composite structures. The digitally synthesized structures exhibit organic shapes and motions with irregular distributions of material phases. Within the structures, different materials play distinct roles yet seamlessly collaborate through sophisticated deformation mechanisms to produce the target behaviors. The proposed synthesis, multimaterial fabrication, and heteroassembly strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. This work provides a general framework for the design of mechanical structures with arbitrary and extreme responses. It also opens up a new avenue for the design of function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The hemoglobin system is a key regulator of the timing of development and differentiation in mammals. Here we show that the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) is a key regulator of the hemoglobin system. IGF2BP1 is expressed in the fetal liver and is silenced in the adult bone marrow. In erythroid cells, IGF2BP1 is expressed at high levels and is able to reprogram the hemoglobin expression pattern. This is achieved by reduced expression of the adult hemoglobin genes and increased expression of the fetal hemoglobin gene. This mechanism may be important for the timing of development and differentiation in mammals.

Ferroptosis is a regulated form of regulated necrosis that is regulated by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. In this study, we found that the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis is essential for ferroptosis resistance in cancer cells, and that this resistance is mediated by the activation of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1/stearoyl-CoA desaturase-1-dependent lipogenesis. In addition, we found that mTORC1 inhibition sensitized cancer cells to ferroptosis, and that this combination resulted in near-complete tumor regression in preclinical models. These findings suggest that mTORC1 inhibition may be a promising strategy for cancer treatment in combination with ferroptosis induction. (Read more)

Hypertension is the leading cause of heart failure. The treatment of hypertension is a major challenge for the medical community. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are calcium channel blockers. These drugs are associated with a high risk of heart failure. We show that these drugs promote vascular remodeling through a mechanism that is not related to the inhibition of the calcium channels.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy for the conservation of biodiversity on federal land. We show that the NWFP halted the decline of bird populations in early-seral forests, but not in older forests. This is partly because of fire on federal land and continued clearcutting elsewhere. The NWFP is a model for policy to conserve biodiversity, but its success depends on continued implementation.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. Therefore, the development of new antibiotics is urgently needed. Here, we present a computational approach to design new antibiotics. The design strategy is based on the prediction of the membrane permeability, binding affinity to the ribosome, and solubility of the compounds. We tested the designed compounds in vitro and in vivo. The best compound designed by us is active against multiple antibiotic-resistant pathogens. This approach can be used to design new antibiotics for other pathogens. We introduce a deep convolutional neural network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters. The architecture is based on a simple idea of using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. The proposed architecture is able to achieve state-of-the-art results in several problems. The code is available at: https://github.com/yannickdelouille/dilated_convnets.git.

The evolution of the African Great Lakes has been a key driver of human migration, animal dispersal, and the diversification of the world’s most diverse freshwater ecosystem. We present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of the hydroclimate of Lake Malawi, East Africa. Our results show that the evolution of the lake was driven by large-scale changes in the effective moisture of the climate. We observe a dramatic shift in the hydroclimate at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition, consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after 800,000 years ago. The lake level variations exerted a profound influence on the evolution of the endemic cichlid fish species flock. The rapid diversification of the species flock was enabled by the reconfiguration of the lake habitat, which allowed for the formation of new ecological niches. The hydroclimate variability of the lake was a key driver of this rapid speciation. These results have important implications for understanding the evolution of the African Great Lakes and the global hydrological cycle. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The use of electronic devices for reading and entertainment has become increasingly popular. However, the effects of such devices on sleep are unknown. Here we show that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device phase-delays the circadian clock, acutely suppresses melatonin, and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety. These results have implications for the design of electronic devices and the timing of their use before bedtime.

The Younger Dryas (YD) chronozone marks a period of global climate change. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the YD cooling. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YD. We show that the Osmium isotope ratios of magnetic grains and microspherules from the YD sites are similar to average upper continental crust, indicating a terrestrial origin of Os in these samples. In contrast, the Os isotope ratios of bulk sediments from YD sites in Belgium and Pennsylvania suggest mixing with extraterrestrial Os, but the Os in these samples is likely terrestrially derived. The rare earth element patterns and Sr and Nd isotopes of spherules from the YD site in Pennsylvania indicate that their source lies in 1.5-Ga Quebecia terrain in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America. These results support the hypothesis that one or more bolide impacts triggered the YD cooling. (Show more)

CTLA-4 is a well-known negative regulator of T cell activation. However, its role in the development of autoimmunity is still unclear. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in adult mice. We found that CTLA-4 deletion induced lymphoproliferation, hypergammaglobulinemia, and histologically evident pneumonitis, gastritis, insulitis, and sialadenitis. However, this was not fatal. This indicates that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity, but not for its survival.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of this group remains poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of 89 genes to estimate the diversification of beetles and traced the evolution of genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of plant cell walls. Our results show that the origin of beetles coincides with the origin of the plant kingdom, and that the evolution of beetles was driven by multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, codiversification with plants, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivores following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding enzymes that digest plant cell walls. These results have important implications for understanding the evolution of beetles and other animals. © 2018, The Author(s).

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is contentious. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. Population size was manipulated such that participants could learn from the paper planes constructed by one, two, or four models from the prior generation. These social-learning conditions were compared with an asocial individual-learning condition in which individual participants made repeated attempts at constructing a paper plane, without having access to any planes produced by other participants. Larger populations generated greater variation in plane performance and gave participants access to better-adapted planes, but this did not enhance CCE. In fact, there was an inverse relationship between population size and CCE: plane flight distance did not improve over the experimental generations in the 2-Model and 4-Model conditions, but did improve over generations in the 1-Model social-learning condition. Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia. APOE is the strongest genetic risk factor for AD. APOE isoform is highly associated with AD risk. APOE is also a major protein of astrocytes, a major cell type in the brain. Here, we show that APOE isoform regulates the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. APOE2 enhances the rate of synapse pruning, whereas APO4 decreases it. We also show that APOE4 increases the rate of C1q accumulation in the brain, which may be due to the increased rate of synapse pruning. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that APOE4 may be associated with AD risk in part due to defective phagocytic capacity of astrocytes, which accelerates the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration. These studies provide a molecular basis for the role of APOE in AD pathogenesis. They also provide a potential therapeutic target for AD treatment. This study also provides a molecular basis for the role of APOE in AD pathogenesis.

The Earth's inner core is a solid sphere with a diameter of 2,890 km. It is the densest part of the planet. The inner core is a mystery because of its origin and structure. The origin of the inner core is still unknown. The structure of the inner core is also unknown. The two problems are related to each other. The two problems are also related to the origin of the Earth.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well studied, the underlying mechanisms are not understood. Here, we show that the brain’s reactivity to methylphenidate (a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine [DA]) is reduced in marijuana abusers, who are more likely to be stressed, irritable, and addicted. These findings suggest that the brain’s reactivity to DA stimulation might contribute to the negative emotionality and addictive behaviors of marijuana abusers.

Language is a uniquely human skill. Despite its importance, the brain mechanisms of language comprehension are only beginning to be understood. Here, we show that the most popular class of deep neural networks, which are trained on large unlabeled data sets, are powerful predictors of neural responses to sentences in humans. This suggests that predictive processing, as implemented by these networks, may be a fundamental mechanism of language comprehension in the human brain. These results have implications for the design of artificial intelligence and for understanding the brain mechanisms of language and other cognitive skills. They also provide a promising avenue for developing computational models of the human brain.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major advance in machine learning. However, it is still a black box, and it is not clear why it works. We show that the success of DL is due to the fact that it is a universal approximator. This means that DL can approximate any function, and it is not limited to any specific function. This is a very strong property, and it is not clear how it can be achieved.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global tragedy. The scientific community has been working hard to understand the virus and its spread. One of the most influential studies on this topic is a classic experiment published in 1972. It is often cited as evidence that people are unable to understand exponential growth. However, the study’s design flaws were not noticed at the time and are now being discussed. This is a unique case study of researchers falling prey to just the cognitive bias they set out to study.

Leprosy is a disease that has plagued humanity for millennia. The causative agents, Mycobacterium leprae for Hansen's disease and Mycobacterium lepromatosis for lepromatous leprosy, are slow-growing, difficult to culture, and have been difficult to study. Here we report the genome sequence of M. lepromatosis, which is a close relative of M. leprae. We show that M. lepromatosis has lost several enzymes required for amino acid synthesis, and that M. leprae has a defective heme pathway. Our findings suggest that the two leprosy bacilli are remarkably conserved and still cause similar pathologic conditions. Our results also provide a foundation for future studies of the evolution of leprosy. (Show more)

Entanglement and entropy are central concepts in quantum mechanics. They are also key ingredients in the description of the thermodynamic limit of isolated systems. However, the study of the evolution of entanglement and entropy in isolated systems is a very challenging task. In this work, we show that the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit can be understood in terms of quasiparticles. This result is a major step toward the understanding of the evolution of entanglement and entropy in isolated systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed the lives of millions of people worldwide. The only available vaccines are inactivated, and the development of a live attenuated vaccine is a major scientific and technological challenge. Here, we describe a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine that is highly protective in a relevant animal model. The vaccine is easy to manufacture, can be stored at 2–8 °C, and is temperature sensitive, which should facilitate its large-scale distribution. This vaccine has the potential to be used in mass vaccination programs to combat the pandemic. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Plague is a disease with a long history of human suffering and mortality. The Second Pandemic (14–19th centuries) led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of the disease is unknown, but it is thought to have been spread by rats. Here, we show that a model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This work may help to understand the history of plague and the evolution of vector control. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The evolution of brain size has been a central topic in the study of animal cognition. However, the evolution of brain power is more complex than just the evolution of brain size. We show that the evolution of brain power is driven by the evolution of the number of neurons. We also show that the evolution of brain power is not only driven by the evolution of body size but also by the evolution of cognitive ability.

TRAP1 (TNF receptor-associated protein) is a mitochondrial molecular chaperone that is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal cells is not well understood. We have used TRAP1-null cells and transient TRAP1 silencing/overexpression to show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. Taken together with the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. Actin filaments are the main structural elements of the cytoskeleton. They are dynamic polymers that can be assembled and disassembled. The disassembly process is regulated by the cofilin family of proteins. Here, we show that the action of cofilin is strongly influenced by the mechanical state of the filament network. We propose a mechanochemical model that explains our experimental observations. Our results have implications for understanding the role of cofilin in cells.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in combination with glucose in beverages and foods. The present study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the mechanisms of obesity and the effects of sugar-sweetened beverages on the brain and behavior. (PsycINFO Database Record

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its human history. The island is home to a unique language and culture, and its genetic diversity is a mixture of both African and Asian ancestry. We used a grid-based approach to sample at high resolution the genomic diversity across Madagascar. We find that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian ancestry. The settlement history of Madagascar is also complex, with a recent population growth and a sex-biased and geographically heterogeneous admixture. These results have implications for the settlement history of Madagascar and for the genetic diversity of the island. They also highlight the importance of considering the geographic distribution of the genetic diversity when studying the human history of an island. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions expressed by others on Facebook. This work has implications for the study of emotional contagion, social psychology, and social network analysis.

The ribosome is a key component of the protein synthesis machinery. The ribosome can encounter RNA modifications during translation, and these modifications can have a profound impact on protein synthesis. In this study, we show that the presence of a modification in the mRNA sequence can impact the translation of that mRNA. We find that the presence of pseudouridine (Ψ) in the mRNA sequence can modestly alter both translation speed and mRNA decoding. Our work suggests that the presence of Ψ in the mRNA sequence can have a small impact on protein synthesis, and that this impact can be observed in both the reconstituted translation system and human cells. This work provides insight into the impact of mRNA modifications on protein synthesis, and may lead to a better understanding of the role of mRNA modifications in health and disease. (Show more)

We show that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, social engagement, and time use. This finding has implications for the design of interventions to promote healthy aging.

The evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is a key feature of the evolution of life in water. We use a model of the energetic constraints on body size to show that the evolution of aquatic mammals is driven toward a size attractor in the water. This attractor is consistent with the energetic constraints of the aquatic medium. The evolution of aquatic mammals is thus driven by the same energetic constraints that drive the evolution of life in water.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. The virus replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. We show that the mouse model of the common cold is a good model for studying the temperature-dependent growth of rhinovirus. We also show that the mouse model is sensitive to the antiviral defense response of infected cells.

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a major cause of infections in the hospital environment. It is an opportunistic pathogen that can cause severe infections in immunocompromised patients, and is responsible for a large number of cases of nosocomial infections. The bacterium is able to adapt to the host environment and to the host immune system, and is able to cause severe infections. The mechanisms that allow the bacterium to adapt to the host environment are poorly understood. Here we show that the bacterium is able to sense the mechanical activity of its pili, which are used for surface attachment. This mechanism is important for the bacterium to adapt to the host environment and to cause severe infections.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the last decades. However, the impact of pesticides on the environment is still poorly understood. We show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions.

SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, has spread globally and is responsible for millions of deaths. Deer are susceptible to SARS-CoV-2 infection, and experimentally infected fawns can transmit the virus. We report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in 33% of free-living deer and 80% of deer sampled during the peak of the deer hunting season. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic. We highlight the need for a robust and proactive “One Health” approach to obtain enhanced understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. Our findings suggest that the virus is circulating in deer and that deer may play a role in the maintenance of the pandemic. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The world is moving toward a more sustainable energy future. This paper examines the proliferation of large dams in developing countries and the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) peptide is the primary pathological hallmark. However, the role of Aβ in the initiation of the disease is still unclear. Here, we show that neurons are the major source of inflammatory factors in AD. This is a neuron-specific inflammatory response, which may precede the formation of amyloid plaques and tau tangles. Thus, we propose that the Aβ-burdened neuron may be a primary target for therapeutic intervention.

The domestic chicken (Gallus gallus domesticus) is one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. The earliest evidence for the use of chickens for economic purposes is still unknown. We present a detailed analysis of the faunal remains from the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, and show that the exploitation of chickens was widespread and practiced on a large scale. We argue that the early adoption of chickens in European husbandry was a consequence of the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy. This process was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later. Our results provide new insights into the history of the domestic chicken and its spread in the ancient world. (Show more)

The folding of a protein is a complex process that is not yet understood. We have studied the folding of the maltose binding protein, a large protein that is a model for the folding of many other proteins. We have found that the folding of the protein is a multistage process. The folding is fast at high concentrations, but at low concentrations the folding is slow. The slow folding is due to a molecular collapse that occurs before the folding is complete.

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been linked to the formation of RNA caps. However, the cellular decapping enzymes that are responsible for removing those caps are not known. Here, we show that the RNA pyrophosphohydrolase RppH, which is known to remove Np4-capped RNAs, is also capable of removing their triphosphorylated and diphosphorylated counterparts. This enzyme recognizes capped RNAs by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to recognize other 5′ termini, resulting in a one-nucleotide shift in substrate specificity. The unconventional manner in which RppH recognizes capped 5′ ends and its differential impact on the rates at which such termini are deprotected as a prelude to RNA degradation could have major consequences for reprogramming gene expression during disulfide stress. Sepsis is a major cause of death worldwide. The mechanisms involved in the development of immunosuppression during sepsis are not fully understood. We hypothesized that arginine, a key amino acid in the immune response, could be a potential therapeutic target in sepsis. We demonstrated that citrulline, a nonproteinogenic amino acid, could increase arginine plasma levels and restore T cell function and proliferation while decreasing the expansion of immunosuppressive cells. These results suggest that citrulline could be a potential therapeutic target in sepsis. This study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. Copyright © 2015. The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined. We also highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass of the biosphere and can be used to better understand the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. This article is protected by copyright. Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in nature and in physics, where a system evolves in time and the system’s activity or “pace” of change is self-regulating. SOC systems are characterized by a power-law distribution of activity. The sandpile model is the first and archetypical model of SOC. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a tropical model with self-organized criticality (SOC) behavior. Our model is continuous, in contrast to all known models of SOC, and is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model. We describe how our model is related to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena and discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide range of applications. It is a promising material for quantum applications, but its properties can be changed by external stimuli. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly by strain engineering. This opens up opportunities for tailoring the properties of diamond for quantum applications.

The role of plant immune peptides in the defense against fungal pathogens is well established. However, the structural basis for their antifungal activity is not well understood. Here, we report the NMR structure of a unique antifungal peptide from the legume Medicago truncatula. This peptide is highly dynamic and has a highly unusual structure. It exhibits potent fungicidal activity against multiple plant fungal pathogens. It binds to multiple bioactive phosphoinositides in vitro. It has strong cell wall binding and penetration of the cell membrane at discrete foci, followed by gradual loss of turgor, subsequent accumulation in the cytoplasm, and elevated levels in nucleoli of germlings. Our work illustrates the antifungal activity of a structurally unique NCR peptide against plant fungal pathogens and paves the way for future development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes. In this study, we show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm undergoes substantial compositional changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that female-derived proteins become enriched in the sperm proteome after mating and during the storage period in the female reproductive tract. These findings provide a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the sperm proteome and expand our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. Our research provides a foundation for future studies of the molecular basis of sperm–FRT interactions and reproductive success. (Show more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, in part, by conformational changes. We show that force can switch the conformation of VWF, providing a mechanism for platelet activation. This mechanism is important for understanding the pathophysiology of von Willebrand disease, a disorder of platelet activation. We show that force can be used to measure the kinetics of the conformational changes in VWF. This method can be used to study other proteins. This article is protected by copyright. The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the human virome, the viral component of the microbiome, has been difficult to study. This is because of the lack of a comprehensive database for human-associated viruses. We have created such a database, which contains over 45,000 unique virus taxa, with over 100 million viral sequences. We use this database to analyze thousands of case-control studies, and find over 2,200 virus–disease associations. This database will be a valuable resource for the microbiome field for years to come.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of ACI processes and the lack of observational capability. Here, we introduce a new instrument, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to investigate ACI. The HSRL is capable of simultaneously profiling aerosol and cloud properties. We demonstrate the capability of the HSRL to investigate ACI. The results show that the aerosol loading has no discernible effect on the liquid water path but increased droplet number concentration and decreased droplet effective radius. This finding supports the hypothesis that aerosol-induced cloud water increase caused by suppressed rain formation can be canceled out by enhanced evaporation. Thus, these observations obtained from the HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has a profound influence on the evolution of life. The temperature of the surface is in turn controlled by the intensity of solar radiation. The intensity of solar radiation, in turn, is controlled by the distance of the Earth from the Sun. Thus, the temperature of the surface is a function of the distance of the Earth from the Sun, which in turn is a function of time. This relationship between the distance of the Earth from the Sun and the temperature of the surface has been used to infer the temperature of the surface of the Earth over geological time. We show that this relationship can be used to infer the temperature of the surface of the Earth over geological time. This finding is consistent with previous interpretations based on isotopic evidence. These findings are important for understanding the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history. Ion channels are the key to the communication between cells and the body. They are the main gatekeeper of the ion flow in the body. The ion flow is essential for the normal function of the body. The ion flow is also the basis for the transmission of nerve impulses. The ion flow is the basis for the transmission of nerve impulses. Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with millions of deaths each year. The parasite exploits the host cell to facilitate entry into the human body. Here, we show that the malaria parasite alters the biophysical properties of the host cell, which is critical for invasion. This finding would have a major impact on our understanding of the malaria parasite and could lead to the development of new strategies to combat this disease. (Show more)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide range of applications. It is a promising material for quantum applications, but its properties can be modified by strain engineering. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly in six-dimensional strain space. We also show that the bandgap of diamond can be made direct by strain engineering. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In the temperate regions, seasonal outbreaks of influenza virus correlate with decreases in ambient humidity. While the impact of humidity on host defense against influenza virus infection is well established, the impact on disease outcome is less clear. Here, we show that housing mice in low humidity increases susceptibility to severe disease following influenza virus challenge. We found that low humidity impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient Mx1 mice, independent of viral burden. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings have implications for the development of strategies to mitigate the impact of influenza virus infection in the temperate regions. This article is protected by copyright. The brain is thought to build syntactic structures in a hierarchical manner, from the simplest to the most complex. However, the neurophysiological evidence for this claim is still lacking. Here, we show that the brain encodes the structure of sentences in a hierarchical manner, as well. We found that the activity in multiple superior temporal and inferior frontal brain sites increased with each successive word in a sentence but decreased suddenly whenever words could be merged into a phrase. Our results suggest that the brain uses a merge operation to build syntactic structures and provide initial evidence for a neural implementation of a bottom-up or left-corner parser of the incoming language stream. Our findings have implications for the study of language and for the design of artificial intelligence. © 2018, The Author(s).

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major signaling pathway in development. It is important for the formation of the body axis, the formation of the limbs, and the formation of the organs. The pathway is also important for the maintenance of the organism. The pathway is regulated by two proteins, β-catenin and Axin. We show here that there are two forms of Axin, Axin1 and Axin2, which are similar at the protein level and genetically redundant. We show that the two forms of Axin are regulated differently on the transcriptional and proteostatic level. This differential regulation confers differential responsiveness that can be used in tissue-specific regulation.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region of the brain that regulates feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH neurons causes vigorous eating in sated animals. We found that this effect is mediated by dopamine neurons in the ventral tegmental area (VTA). We also found that stimulation-induced eating is blocked by lesions of the VTA or dopamine neurons in the substantia nigra. Finally, we found that stimulation-induced eating is blocked by lesions of peri-LH GABA neurons, which project to the VTA. Thus, we have characterized a circuit that may promote overeating and contribute to obesity.

Nitrogen is the most limiting nutrient for plant growth. The ability to control the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis between plants and bacteria would allow for the delivery of nitrogen in a sustainable manner. Here, we have developed a system that allows for the control of the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis in barley. This system is based on the production of the bacterial signal rhizopine by barley. We have also developed a genetic circuit that allows for the control of the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis in the bacterium. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work may lead to the development of a sustainable nitrogen-fixing symbiosis in agriculture. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We study the effects of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon. The program was randomly assigned to 39 of 76 communities. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. The results suggest that the program may contribute to sustainable forest management.

The sense of hearing is a fundamental ability of many animals. The auditory organs of these animals are extremely diverse in anatomy after hundreds of millions of years of evolution, yet they are all made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the body. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is extended through outsourcing hearing to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web. We find that the web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to capture the sound-induced air particle movements that approach the maximum physical efficiency better than the acoustic responsivity of all previously known eardrums. By sensing the motion of web threads, the spider remotely detects and localizes the source of an incoming airborne acoustic wave. The spider enables the flexibility to functionally adjust and regularly regenerate its external "eardrum" according to its needs. The outsourcing and supersizing of auditory function in spiders provide unique features for studying extended and regenerative sensing and designing novel acoustic flow detectors for precise fluid dynamic measurement and manipulation. We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C. We also show that aerosols mask the anthropogenic rise in global temperature, and that removing pollution particles liberates 0.51(±0.03) °C and all pollution particles 0.73(±0.03) °C warming. We conclude that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

COVID-19 is a global pandemic with no cure or vaccine. We report the design, synthesis, and characterization of a variant of the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein receptor-binding domain (RBD) that exhibits enhanced immunogenicity and cross-reactivity with variants of concern. This engineered RBD can be expressed on a virus-like particle (VLP) and is well-suited for large-scale manufacturing. This engineered RBD may be a useful tool for vaccine development and for the development of diagnostics. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The ALK family of receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) is involved in the development of many tissues. In addition, ALK family members are implicated in the development of cancer. In this study, we show that zebrafish ALK homologs are involved in the development of neural crest-derived tissues. We further show that the zebrafish ALK homologs are able to activate the human ALK homolog. Our results provide in vivo evidence of the involvement of the ALK family of RTKs in neural crest development and in the development of cancer. This study provides a foundation for future studies on the role of ALK family members in cancer and in the development of other tissues. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and the emergence of the plague pathogen Yersinia pestis from a Yersinia pseudotuberculosis-like progenitor is one of the most important events in the history of human disease. We present 17 Y. pestis genomes from 5,000 to 2,500 y BP, which provide a more complete picture of the evolution of plague during this critical period. Our results suggest that plague was not a commensal of the flea until the Bronze Age, and that the plague pathogen diversified slowly over time. These data provide insights into the early evolution of plague and its relationship to its vector, which may have been key to its success. (Show more)

This work examined the role of the culturally endorsed form of masculinity (hegemonic masculinity) in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump in the 2016 and 2020 American presidential elections. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, we found that women’s and men’s endorsement of hegemonic masculinity predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of hegemonic masculinity legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class hierarchies via candidate support. The conversion of grassland to cropland has led to massive losses of soil organic carbon (SOC) to the atmosphere. However, the efficacy of soil health management practices in reversing this trend remains highly uncertain. We show that soil health management practices can increase SOC storage and mineral-associated organic matter in a long-term field experiment. These practices also enhanced the activity of soil microbes, but did not increase the abundance of microbes that are known to be associated with soil health. These results highlight the key role of well-managed grasslands in climate-smart agriculture.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans. We developed a framework to identify and prioritize wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to spillover and cause disease in humans. We validated the framework using data from a virus discovery project and public records of virus detections around the world. The resulting ranking of 887 viruses was validated by the known zoonotic origin of the majority of the top 12. The SpillOver platform provides a living, interactive database that can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for reproduction. The color of nectar is a key trait that attracts pollinators, but the chemical basis for this adaptation is poorly understood. Here, we show that the red color of the nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We demonstrate that this compound is attractive to the vertebrate-pollinated species Phelsuma geckos. Our findings provide evidence for convergent evolution of this trait in two distantly related species. This work suggests that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The genetic history of Europe is a complex story of migrations and invasions. However, the genetic history of the population during the period of the so-called Migration Period (5th–7th centuries AD) is largely unknown. Here we present a genome-wide analysis of a group of 11 individuals from Bavaria, Germany, who died mostly between 480 and 650 AD. Our results indicate that the genetic ancestry of the majority of men is of northern and central European origin, while the genetic ancestry of women is very heterogeneous and includes signals of genetic ancestry from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, we found that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. Our results indicate that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape. © 2018, The Author(s).

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) currently spreads in humans and causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) is responsible for replicating the lagging strand template during DNA replication. The stability of the pol δ holoenzyme is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. In this study, we developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. We found that the human pol δ holoenzyme maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. Our results provide a mechanistic explanation for the unique properties of pol δ and may have implications for the design of new DNA polymerases for therapeutic applications. The origin of life is one of the most important problems in science. In this paper, we report the first demonstration of the replication of genetic information in the absence of proteins. This work is a major step toward the reconstruction of RNA-based life.

We use computer vision methods to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: the density of college-educated adults, the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and the proximity of the neighborhood to other physically attractive neighborhoods. These results are consistent with three classical theories of urban change. Our results provide a new way to study the physical dynamics of cities and may be useful for urban planners and policymakers. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

COVID-19 is a highly infectious disease. The clinical manifestations are diverse, and the mortality is high. The treatment is still in the early stage. We have found that tocilizumab, which targets interleukin 6, can improve the clinical outcome immediately. It is an effective treatment to reduce mortality.

Copper is an essential micronutrient for all organisms, but its excess is toxic. The ability to regulate copper content is therefore a key to the survival of all organisms. In this study, we demonstrate that the xan biosynthetic gene cluster of Aspergillus fumigatus is involved in the regulation of intracellular copper content. We also show that xan BGC-derived isocyanides are secreted and have antimicrobial properties. These results suggest that the xan BGC is involved in the regulation of copper homeostasis and the interaction of fungi with competing microbes. This article is protected by copyright. The formation of tridymite, a low-pressure, high-temperature (>870 °C) polymorph of SiO2, in a sedimentary mudstone at Gale crater, Mars, is consistent with the presence of silicic volcanism in the region. The tridymite is cogenetic with the other crystalline minerals, and the amorphous silica is derived from multiple aqueous solutions. The presence of tridymite in a sedimentary environment is a first for Mars.

Frost damage is a major threat to plant productivity and a major cause of economic losses in agriculture and forestry. We show that the geographic distribution of frost damage is changing in response to climate change. We also show that the resistance strategies of trees to frost damage are region-specific and that these strategies are changing in response to climate change. Our findings can inform land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are critical for the pathogenesis of certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the mechanisms by which they contribute to disease are not well understood. Here, we show that Th17 cells can contribute to colitis pathogenesis in two ways: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. These results have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for inflammatory bowel disease. (Show more)

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, leading to paralysis and death. We now report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients with ALS. These cells can be used to study disease mechanisms and test potential therapeutics. This method will enable high-throughput screening of drugs to identify those that alleviate toxicity to motor neurons. This will accelerate ALS research and lead to the development of new therapies. This method will also be useful for other neurodegenerative diseases. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The gut microbiota is a critical factor in the health and fitness of many animals, including ticks. However, the ways in which infectious agents influence the composition of the tick microbiota are poorly understood. Here, we show that the tick-borne pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces the expression of antifreeze glycoprotein (iafgp), which alters the composition of the tick microbiota. IAFGP binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the pentapeptide chain of bacterial peptidoglycan, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These data elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This work provides insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the composition of the vector microbiota and may lead to the development of new strategies to control vector-borne diseases. The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the history of tetrapods. The short tail of modern birds is a derived feature that evolved from a long tail in basal birds. The study of the evolution of the avian tail is therefore critical for understanding the origin and diversification of modern birds. Here, we describe a new basal member of the short-tailed bird group, Jinguofortis perplexus, from the Early Cretaceous of China. Our study increases the known diversity of early members of the short-tailed bird group and provides insights into the evolution of the avian tail. (Show more)

The climate system is a complex system, and it is difficult to understand it. However, we can use observations and models to understand the main features of the climate system. Here we show that the stratosphere plays an important role in the climate system.

Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue. The color of an animal is important for its survival, as it can be used to assess its fitness and reproductive success. In this study, we show that the color of anurans (frogs and toads) can be changed by the presence of a group of proteins that bind biliverdin, a pigment that is normally present in the blood. Our results provide evidence of recurrent evolution of chlorosis, a phenomenon that is common in vertebrates, and describe a biliverdin-binding protein in vertebrates. Our findings have implications for understanding the evolution of color in vertebrates and for the study of the biology of anurans. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Hypoxia is a common feature of many cancers, and is associated with poor prognosis. We show that hypoxia induces breast cancer stem cells (BCSCs) in MDA-MB-231 human breast cancer cells. We also show that hypoxia induces expression of AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), a m6A demethylase, which increases NANOG mRNA levels and the percentage of BCSCs. Thus, ALKBH5 expression is induced by hypoxia, and is required for the enrichment of BCSCs in the hypoxic tumor microenvironment. Our results suggest that ALKBH5 may be a therapeutic target for breast cancer treatment.

The earliest pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century. The source of the parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. The Latin term abortivum in many sources has led some scholars to suggest that fetal calves or sheep skins were used. Others have argued that it would not be possible to sustain herds if so many pocket Bibles were made from fetal skins, arguing instead for unexpected alternatives, such as rabbit. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. The noninvasive method is a variant on zooarchaeology by mass spectrometry (ZooMS) peptide mass fingerprinting but extracts protein from the parchment surface by using an electrostatic charge generated by gentle rubbing of a PVC eraser on the membrane surface. Using this method, we analyzed 72 pocket Bibles originating in France, England, and Italy and 293 additional parchment samples that bracket this period. The Permian-Triassic extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age model for this extinction is critical for understanding its cause and the controls on extinction/recovery dynamics. We present a precise age model for the extinction based on U-Pb dating of volcanic ash beds. The extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. Onset of a major reorganization of the carbon cycle immediately precedes the initiation of extinction and is punctuated by a sharp (3‰), short-lived negative spike in the isotopic composition of carbonate carbon. Carbon cycle volatility persists for ∼500 ka before a return to near preextinction values. Decamillenial to millennial level resolution of the mass extinction and its aftermath will permit a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction, allowing insight into postextinction ecosystem expansion. Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a transcription factor that plays important roles in the regulation of various biological processes. However, the intestinal epithelial cell (IEC)-specific role of RORα remains unclear. Here, we generated IEC-specific RORα-deficient mice and found that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. RORαΔIEC mice exhibit excessive intestinal inflammation and highly activated inflammatory responses in the dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) mouse colitis model.
