The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for neutralizing antibodies and T cells. We have determined the structure of the spike protein in complex with the ACE2 receptor and the cellular protein Neuropilin-1. We show that the receptor binding domain of the spike protein is flexible and can adopt a variety of conformations. This flexibility may facilitate the interaction with the ACE2 receptor. Our results provide insights into the mechanism of action of the spike protein and may help in the development of new therapeutics and vaccines. (Show more)

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs. Our results extend to a large class of games with tail-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that the pandemic has resulted in a reduction in life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y, lower than any year since 2003. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites, would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006. These findings underscore the need for policies that address structural inequalities in health outcomes. © 2020, The Author(s).

The chemical properties of atoms are of fundamental importance in chemistry. In this work, we show that pressure can change the chemical properties of atoms. This is of great importance for understanding the chemistry of matter under pressure. Furthermore, we show that the chemical properties of atoms can be used to predict and explain the chemistry of matter under pressure.

Fire is a natural and important disturbance in terrestrial ecosystems. Changes in fire activity can affect the global carbon cycle, but the direction of change is poorly understood. We show that changes in human demography tend to suppress global fire activity, keeping more carbon within terrestrial ecosystems and attenuating warming. Our results highlight the importance of fire in mitigating climate change, and the need to consider fire in climate policy.

The gut microbiota of animals is a major player in host health and development. However, the mechanisms by which the host regulates the composition of the microbiota are largely unknown. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the activities of its luminescent symbionts through the strategic provision of a single glycan, chitin. This glycan is catabolized by the symbionts, which in turn modulates the pH of the host crypts. This pH change enhances the activity of the symbionts, which in turn provide a benefit to the host by producing light at night. This study provides a new perspective on the role of host-derived nutrients in the regulation of the gut microbiota. (Show more)

Text data are ubiquitous and are increasingly used to understand the world. However, the latent patterns in text data are often not understood. We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data and represent documents as topic sequences. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data.

The Black Death, which originated in Asia, arrived in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe in 1347 CE. This epidemic marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. The identity of the rodent reservoir of this disease has been debated for centuries. We show that the climate conditions in Asia and Europe were favorable for the introduction of plague into European harbors, and that the bacterium was reintroduced into Europe at regular intervals of 15 ± 1 y. Our results suggest that the rodent reservoir of the plague was not in Europe, but in Asia. This finding has important implications for the search for the plague reservoir. It also has implications for the understanding of the spread of the disease in Europe. (Show more)

Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web. They are an important prey for a variety of predators, including sea stars. In the Northeast Pacific, a disease has recently emerged that causes rapid death of sea stars. The disease is caused by a virus. We show that the virus is the most likely cause of the disease.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia and is associated with a poor prognosis. The identification of candidate leukemic stem cells is a major challenge in the treatment of AML. We show here that monoclonal antibodies targeting the IL1RAP (IL1R3) receptor on candidate AML stem cells have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. We further show that an antibody targeting IL1RAP can be used to target IL-1 signaling and to treat primary human AML cells. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. The results also provide a proof of principle for the use of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of other diseases. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its human history. We used a grid-based approach to sample at high resolution the genomic diversity (including maternal lineages, paternal lineages, and genome-wide data) across 257 villages and 2,704 Malagasy individuals. We find a common Bantu and Austronesian descent for all Malagasy individuals with a limited paternal contribution from Europe and the Middle East. Admixture and demographic growth happened recently, suggesting a rapid settlement of Madagascar during the last millennium. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, there are geographic influences on the present genomic diversity, independent of the admixture, showing that a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. Our results provide insights into the human history of Madagascar and the settlement of the island. They also provide a reference for the study of human diversity and the settlement of other islands. Bacteria use small RNAs to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The RNA encodes a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC) that interacts with glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase and increases dehydrogenase activity. We found that overexpression of the RNA encoding AzuC results in a growth defect in glycerol and galactose medium. The defect in galactose medium was still observed for a stop codon mutant derivative, suggesting a second role for the RNA. Interestingly, AzuC translation interferes with the observed repression of cadA and galE by the RNA and base pairing interferes with AzuC translation, demonstrating that the translation and base-pairing functions compete. This work provides insight into the evolution of dual-function RNAs and the mechanisms by which they function. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants.

Crop experts are the first line of defense for farmers in the US. They provide information on the status of crops at the county level, and are the source of the official crop progress and condition data published by the US Department of Agriculture. We show that the crop expert assessments are a rich source of information that can be used to monitor crop status and predict crop yields. We propose a quantitative Crop Condition Index based on the crop expert assessments, and demonstrate that it can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. Our results show that the crop expert assessments are a valuable source of information that can be used to improve agricultural decision-making.

Language processing is a complex task that involves the integration of information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory in the brain that is based on changes in the excitability of single neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it is able to bind linguistic features over time. This is a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of critical importance. However, despite decades of research, the response of soil respiration to warming remains unclear. We synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The evolution of the plastid genome is a key element in understanding the origin and evolution of life on Earth. The transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle is a major event in the evolution of life, which has been linked to the loss of photosynthesis. However, the evolutionary history of the plastid genome under a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle is still poorly understood. Here, we show that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on the plastid genome in a stepwise manner. Our findings provide a new perspective on the evolution of the plastid genome and its relationship to the evolution of life. They also provide a model for the evolution of the plastid genome under novel environmental conditions. (Show more)

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the risks of climate change to water security. We use a high-resolution large ensemble to estimate the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in southwestern South Africa. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. This work is a first step toward quantifying the risk of anthropogenic climate change to water security in SSA. Future work should focus on the economic impact of such droughts. (Show more)

The discovery of quasicrystals has revolutionized condensed matter physics. The first example of a quasicrystal was discovered in 1984, but the conditions under which they are formed are still not fully understood. Here, we report the discovery of a second example of a quasicrystal, in a sample of red trinitite, the first test explosion of a nuclear bomb. The discovery of this second example of a quasicrystal demonstrates that the conditions for the formation of quasicrystals are not unique to nature and that they are also suitable for the synthesis of new quasicrystal-forming materials. This discovery also provides a link between the history of the 20th century and the science of quasicrystals. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Photosynthesis is the most important process on Earth. It is powered by light, which is converted to chemical energy. The conversion of light energy to chemical energy is mediated by the chlorophyll pigments. The biosynthesis of these pigments is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. The formation of the fifth ring of the chlorophyll molecule is a key step in the biosynthesis of the chlorophyll pigments. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated enzymes. The majority of anoxygenic phototrophic bacteria use a [4Fe-4S] cluster protein, whereas plants, cyanobacteria, and some phototrophic bacteria possess a diiron protein. This work shows that the diiron protein is the cyclase in oxygenic phototrophs, and that different classes of the enzyme exist based on their requirement for an additional subunit. These data delineate three classes of O2-dependent cyclase in chlorophototrophic organisms from higher plants to bacteria, and their evolution is discussed herein. (Read more)

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature of neurodegenerative diseases. Neuroinflammation is also known to be associated with autoimmune diseases, such as multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroinflammation is associated with the activation of mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase (MAP3K) ASK1. In this study, we found that ASK1 plays a critical role in the progression of EAE. We also found that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in the generation and maintenance of disease. Our findings suggest that ASK1 is a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. These findings also suggest that the timing of ASK1 deletion is critical for the treatment of EAE. Our results provide insights into the pathophysiology of EAE and suggest that ASK1 may be a promising therapeutic target for the treatment of EAE. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

California is currently in the midst of a record-setting drought. The drought began in 2012 and has led to acute water shortages, groundwater overdraft, critically low streamflow, and enhanced wildfire risk. We find that precipitation deficits that occurred when conditions were warm were more than twice as likely to yield drought years. We also find that although there has not been a substantial change in the probability of either negative or moderately negative precipitation anomalies in recent decades, the occurrence of drought years has been greater in the past two decades than in the preceding century. We conclude that anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability of co-occurring warm–dry conditions like those that have created the acute human and ecosystem impacts associated with the “exceptional” 2012–2014 drought in California.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability. Therefore, it is difficult to identify the causal genes. We used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. Our results suggest that behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting is a core mechanism of autism. This study provides a framework for understanding the etiology of autism and for developing treatments. (PsycINFO Database Record

This work is the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date. It also highlights individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. These results are important for understanding the prevalence of negative news content around the world, and for informing the design of more positive news content.

Stormorken syndrome is a rare disorder characterized by thrombocytopenia, bleeding diathesis, miosis, and tubular myopathy. Here, we show that the disorder is caused by gain-of-function mutations in STIM1, which are responsible for constitutive activation of the store-operated Ca2+ entry (SOCE) channel. We further show that the SOCE channel is also activated by a loss-of-function mutation in ORAI1, which is responsible for the congenital miosis and tubular aggregate myopathy of the Stormorken syndrome. Our findings expand our understanding of the molecular function of the SOCE channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. (Read more)

Neurodegenerative diseases are among the most common causes of death worldwide. The mechanisms that lead to the accumulation and aggregation of misfolded proteins are poorly understood. Here we show that the spreading of aggregates in a model of Huntington’s disease is non–cell-autonomous and that they are internalized and accumulate within other neurons. These aggregates are not only toxic to the cell of origin but also to other neurons in the brain. We show that the release of aggregates requires fusion protein 1, demonstrating that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. Our results provide insights into the mechanisms of spreading of aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. Bats are increasingly recognized as potential reservoirs of many zoonotic viruses. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are not well understood. Here, we identified and characterized a protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. MTX is a potent immunosuppressant that selectively inhibits the epoxide hydrolase function of leukotriene-A4 hydrolase (LTA4H) to inhibit LTA4 hydrolysis and the generation of leukotriene B4 (LTB4), a potent lipid chemoattractant for host defense against infection. MTX potently inhibited proinflammatory proteases to induce immune tolerance and maintain high stability. In mouse models, influenza A virus (IAV) infection and pathogenicity were exacerbated by MTX but were reversed by interfering with the effects of MTX on LTA4H or exogenous LTB4 administration. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. Our findings may help to understand the mechanisms of virus spillover from bats and provide a deeper understanding of

Cancer is a disease of uncontrolled cell growth. One of the key metabolic changes in cancer is the diversion of one-carbon units from normal cell growth. This diversion is accomplished by the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT). Here we show that SHMT1/2 knockout blocks colon cancer tumor growth. We also identify a small-molecule dual inhibitor of SHMT1/2. This compound is effective in cancer cell lines, but paradoxically increases cytotoxicity in a cell line model of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. This effect is rooted in defective glycine import, which is a targetable metabolic deficiency of this cancer. Thus, we have identified a metabolic target and a therapeutic strategy for cancer. This work has implications for the treatment of other cancers, as well as for the treatment of lymphoma. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The presence of proteins that are supersaturated in the brain and spinal cord of patients with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) suggests that these proteins are prone to aggregation. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord of patients with ALS are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. Rather, the proteins that form inclusions are supersaturated even more than the native interaction partners. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. Our results provide a mechanistic explanation for the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusions in ALS. They also suggest that the presence of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons may be a general feature of neurodegenerative diseases. (Read more)

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The device is scalable to large arrays of atoms and can be deployed in a wide range of applications. This work opens up a new platform for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. This work is expected to be of interest to the physics and engineering communities.

The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the history of life. The study of the origin of the flowering plants is hampered by the lack of fossils. Here we present a detailed study of Montsechia vidalii, a plant from the Cretaceous of Spain. The study of this plant, together with the study of other Cretaceous plants, opens the possibility that aquatic plants were common at an early stage of angiosperm evolution.

Parvoviruses are small, circular, single-stranded DNA viruses that are responsible for a number of conditions in humans. The evolution of parvoviruses has been studied using genetic sequences from living species, but the evolution of the most recent common ancestor of all parvoviruses is unknown. Here we present 10 ancient parvovirus genomes from dental and skeletal remains of individuals who lived in Eurasia and Greenland from ∼0.5 to ∼6.9 thousand years ago. We find that the most recent common ancestor of all parvoviruses is placed ∼12.6 kya, and we are able to date the recombination event between genotypes 1 and 3 that formed genotype 2 to ∼5.0–6.8 kya. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Show more)

Sea level is rising on a global scale, and this rise is accelerating. This acceleration is a result of a combination of factors, including climate change, land subsidence, and ocean warming. We find that the acceleration of global mean sea level is 0.084 mm/y2, which is in agreement with the IPCC AR5. This acceleration is consistent with the hypothesis that the climate is changing, and we conclude that the climate is changing and is causing sea level to rise.

Pain is a common and costly problem. We show that pain is increasing with age in America today, but that it is also increasing with age for those with less education. This increase is not explained by changes in occupation or levels of obesity. It is consistent with the erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. Here, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to characterize the structure and dynamics of a key reaction intermediate in a β-elimination reaction catalyzed by tryptophan synthase. This work highlights the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a detailed picture of the structure and reactivity of reaction intermediates. This work also demonstrates the utility of NMR-assisted crystallography in the study of enzyme mechanisms. This approach may be extended to other enzymes and reaction intermediates, and may be applied to a wide range of chemical and biological problems. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe pneumonia caused by a coronavirus. There is no specific treatment for MERS, and the mortality rate is high. We tested the efficacy of remdesivir, a broad-spectrum antiviral drug, in a nonhuman primate model of MERS-CoV infection. Remdesivir treatment was effective in preventing disease, and in reducing virus replication and lung lesions. These data support the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial of MERS-CoV infection. It may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This would be of benefit to patients, healthcare workers, and the wider community. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The gut microbiota of animals is a major player in host health and development. However, the mechanisms by which the host regulates the composition of the microbiota are largely unknown. Here, we show that the delivery of a single glycan, chitin, is sufficient to regulate the activity of a luminescent symbiont of a squid. This glycan is released by host immune cells in the evening, when the squid is at its most vulnerable to predation. We propose that this strategy is used by hosts to regulate the activity of their gut microbiota. This work provides a new perspective on the role of glycans in the evolution of animal–microbe interactions. (Show more)

Suspension rates in US schools have risen sharply in recent decades. This study shows that teachers can be encouraged to adopt an empathic rather than punitive mindset about discipline. This change in mindset, in turn, bolstered respect for teachers and sustained students’ motivation to behave well in class. These findings have implications for the design of scalable interventions to reduce suspension rates. They also have implications for the design of school discipline policies more generally.

DNA alkylation is a major cause of mutagenesis and cancer. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. Here, we systematically investigated the effects of alkylation on the transcription process. We found that the transcription process is sensitive to the regioisomeric alkylation of DNA. The transcription process is strongly inhibited by alkylation of the major groove. The transcription process is also sensitive to the size of the alkyl group. The transcription process is strongly inhibited by alkylation of the minor groove. These findings provide important mechanistic insights into the effects of alkylation on transcription. The findings also provide a foundation for the development of new strategies for the prevention and treatment of cancer. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) infects humans from zoonotic sources and causes severe pulmonary disease. Virions require spike (S) glycoproteins for binding to cell receptors and for catalyzing virus–cell membrane fusion. Fusion occurs only after S proteins are cleaved sequentially, first during their secretion through the exocytic organelles of virus-producing cells, and second after virus binding to target-cell receptors. To more precisely determine how sequential proteolysis contributes to CoV infection, we introduced S mutations obstructing the first cleavages. These mutations severely compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into several other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. The food system is a major contributor to global warming and pollution. The food choices of the majority of the population have a large impact on the environment and health. We show that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a cafeteria by 50% led to a 40% increase in vegetarian meal sales. This is equivalent to a 60% increase in vegetarian meal sales in the population. This is a simple and effective way to make a large contribution to the sustainability of the food system.

Cancer is a disease of the cell surface, and the surfaceome is the interface for the cell to engage the extracellular space. Here we apply a method for the quantitative analysis of N-linked glycoproteins to study the surfaceome of a panel of six of the most prominent oncogenes in breast cancer. We find that each oncogene has a different surfaceome, but that the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work provides a resource for the breast cancer community and beyond. The data are available at https://doi.org/10.6084/m9.figshare.17182228.v1.

The 2020 presidential election will be the first in which voters will be able to cast their ballots by mail. As a result, there has been a surge of interest in the effects of vote-by-mail programs. However, the evidence on the effects of vote-by-mail is mixed. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, vote share, or party share of the popular vote. Vote-by-mail modestly increases overall average turnout rates. Our results support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media.

SARS-CoV-2 is the cause of the COVID-19 pandemic. The role of accessory proteins in the virus’s ability to cause disease is unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2. This interface is formed by a sequence that is also present in SARS-CoV-2 ORF7a, suggesting that the two proteins may form a larger complex. This work provides insight into the molecular basis of the unique properties of SARS-CoV-2. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common condition in the human body. However, the mechanisms of cerebral edema induced by hypoxia are not well understood. Here we show that hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this is mediated by the release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus. CRF acts on the cerebral cortex via its receptor CRFR1 to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. These findings provide a molecular basis for the pathogenesis of cerebral edema induced by hypoxia. They also suggest that CRFR1 may be a potential target for the treatment of cerebral edema. The world is full of associations. We are interested in the ones that are important. This is the problem of selective inference. We describe some recent developments in this area. We illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis.

The generation of endothelial cells (ECs) is a critical step for the formation of vascular networks. However, the generation of ECs from nonvascular cells is still a challenge. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) can directly induce the generation of endothelial cells from fibroblasts. This study provides a new strategy for the generation of ECs and the formation of vascular networks. Furthermore, the ETV2-induced ECs can improve blood flow recovery in a hind limb ischemic model. These findings provide a new strategy for the treatment of ischemic disorders. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The orphan receptor tyrosine kinases anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) are important drivers of cancer. Here, we show that the augmentor ligands of Alk and Ltk are essential for the development of iridophores, a specialized class of photoreceptors. We demonstrate that the augmentor ligands are essential for the development of iridophores in the eye and the body. These findings establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. These results provide insights into the physiological function of augmentor ligands and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for cancer. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a major health problem. Although the molecular basis of T2D is still unclear, insulin resistance and β-cell dysfunction are two main molecular bases yet to be further elucidated. Herein, we found that STING plays a role in the regulation of insulin sensitivity and β-cell function. Specifically, STING deficiency in β-cells caused impaired glucose-stimulated insulin secretion, which was associated with down-regulation of Pax6. These findings provide a molecular basis for the role of STING in the regulation of insulin sensitivity and β-cell function. Moreover, our study suggests that STING might be a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of T2D. Copyright © 2018. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Influenza A viruses are responsible for the annual occurrence of influenza epidemics and occasional pandemics. The genome of the virus is segmented into eight fragments, which complicates the packaging process. We identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral RNA segments of an influenza A virus. This interaction is required for optimal viral replication and favors the copackaging of the interacting RNA segments. Our results indicate that the interaction between viral RNA segments is sequence dependent and might be a key step in the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome. This interaction might be important for the maintenance of genetic stability of the virus and for the prevention of reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is the leading cause of death worldwide. The development of atherosclerotic lesions is a complex process that involves a series of events, including the activation of proinflammatory and proproliferative phenotypes of endothelial cells (ECs). The objective of this study is to investigate the functional role of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) in the flow regulation of atheroprone phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions. Our results demonstrate that the activation of YAP/TAZ by disturbed flow is critical for the development of atheroprone phenotypes and atherosclerotic lesions. Therefore, inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising athero-protective therapeutic strategy. Our study provides a mechanistic insight into the role of YAP/TAZ in the flow regulation of ECs and the development of atherosclerotic lesions. These findings may lead to the development of athero-protective strategies. (Show more)

Wildfire is a natural process that has shaped the landscape of the United States for millennia. However, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen substantially in recent decades. Climate change has likely contributed to the increase in wildfire activity, but the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Human-caused wildfires disproportionally occurred where fuel moisture was higher than lightning-caused fires, thereby helping expand the geographic and seasonal niche of wildfire. Actions to raise awareness and increase management in regions prone to human-started wildfires should be a focus of United States policy to reduce fire risk and associated hazards.

We use computer vision methods to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We find that neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also have implications for the design of urban policy.

Natural repellents are an ecological method of pest control. However, their molecular targets in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities. The mechanisms of disease are not fully understood, but the within-host dynamics of ZIKV infection are likely important. Here we present a mathematical model of ZIKV infection in a nonhuman primate model. We use the model to estimate the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We also assess the effect of an antiviral treatment on the time to undetectable plasma viral load. Our results can be used to guide the design of future clinical trials. (Show more)

Coral bleaching is a well-known phenomenon that occurs when corals lose their symbiotic zooxanthellae, resulting in the loss of the majority of the coral’s photosynthetic capacity. The underlying causes of bleaching are still poorly understood. Here, we show that the metabolic activity of the coral host is the primary driver of the breakdown of the symbiosis. We demonstrate that the catabolism of amino acids during heat stress leads to an increase in the release of ammonium, which in turn promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates. Together, these processes form a feedback loop that will gradually lead to the decoupling of carbon translocation from the symbiont to the host. Our findings provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. The intestinal epithelium is a barrier between the host and the environment. In the presence of tumors, the epithelium becomes leaky, leading to the loss of nutrients and the overgrowth of opportunistic bacteria. We show that the microbiome can influence the activity of the tumor-suppressor pathway JNK, which in turn regulates the integrity of the intestinal epithelium. Our work identifies a mechanism by which the microbiome can influence the activity of a tumor-suppressor pathway, and it highlights the importance of controlling the activity of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. These findings have implications for the treatment of cancer and the development of probiotics. They also provide a model for the study of the interaction between tumors and the microbiome in other organs. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Chemotherapy is a major treatment for breast cancer, but many patients do not respond well to this therapy. We show that the expression of the type I tyrosine kinase-like orphan receptor ROR1 is increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. We also show that ROR1 enhances the capacity of breast cancer cells to metastasize and to reestablish tumors in Rag2−/−γc−/− mice. Finally, we show that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts (PDXs) with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab is more effective than treatment with paclitaxel alone in eradicating PDXs. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (Show more)

The timing of the start of accelerated Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is still debated. We show that the start of deglaciation was caused by a volcanic eruption of Mount Takahe, which led to stratospheric ozone depletion and a strong El Niño-like climate event. This finding has important implications for the interpretation of the timing of the start of deglaciation and the role of volcanic forcing in the past.

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people worldwide. However, they are often overlooked in conservation and management efforts. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of the world’s catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. Our analysis also reveals that freshwater fisheries are particularly important for the nutrition and livelihoods of the poor. However, intensive fishing in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors may undermine efforts to conserve biodiversity. Our data can be used to improve the inclusion of inland fisheries in environmental planning to protect both food security and species diversity.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge. The safety of aqueous Li-ion batteries is limited by the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material (i.e., LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2) is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The capacity of LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2 is as high as 170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. The ability to regenerate after injury is a key feature of development and a valuable property for the adult nervous system. However, the mechanisms that control regeneration in the adult brain are poorly understood. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway. This discovery has implications for understanding the molecular control of regeneration in the adult brain and for developing strategies to promote regeneration in the CNS.

Recombination is the process by which genetic material is exchanged between two DNA sequences. It is essential for the maintenance of genetic diversity and the evolution of new traits. In this study, we describe the distribution of recombination across the genome of a flowering plant, Mimulus guttatus. We find that recombination rates vary widely across the genome, with some regions experiencing no recombination at all. We also find that recombination is more likely to occur at the start of genes than in the middle or end of genes. These results are similar to those observed in yeast and in mice with a knockout of a positive-regulatory domain zinc finger protein 9. This suggests that recombination patterns in plants may be more similar to those in yeast than to those in animals. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The resting brain is a dynamic system, with fluctuations in functional connectivity reflecting the activity of a large number of brain regions. The identification of these dynamic networks is a major challenge in the field. Here, we show that the dominant resting state network in healthy subjects is topographically similar to the default mode network. In Parkinson’s disease, this dominant network was subordinated to a disease-related pattern. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying the expression of the dominant resting state network in cerebral blood flow PET scans acquired at rest and during task performance. We found that the dominant resting state network was deactivated during task performance, and that this abnormality was partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. This work provides a direct link between the resting organization of the brain and its functional role.

RNA modifications are important for the function of many RNAs in the cell. Here we describe a 5′ cap structure in yeast that is modified by nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+). We show that this cap is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs. This cap structure may have a role in regulating the stability and translation of specific classes of mRNAs.

The persistence of epigenetic DNA methylation (DNA-me) alterations at specific loci over two different time points in people with diabetes is a novel finding. This finding supports an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory, the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy during the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) on the progression of microvascular outcomes in the long-term follow-up Epidemiology of Diabetes Interventions and Complications (EDIC) Study. These results may have implications for the development of new therapeutic strategies for the prevention and treatment of diabetes complications. Copyright © 2015. Published by Elsevier Inc.

Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer. The role of fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) in TNBC has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 is highly expressed in TNBC and is associated with poor prognosis. FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. (Show more)

Alcohol dependence is a major public health problem. The present study shows that some, but not all, alcohol-dependent subjects develop gut leakiness, which is associated with depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in alcohol-dependent subjects. These results suggest that the gut microbiota may be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals. Many of these compounds are nitrogenous, and the biosynthetic pathways for these compounds are unknown. Here we report the identification of a gene (SlTNH1) that is essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. We show that this gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylations of precursors to produce the volatiles. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of tomato flavor and will be of interest to the flavor chemistry community. (Show more)

Biodiversity loss and global warming are two of the most profound threats to the functioning of ecosystems. However, these factors are most frequently investigated separately, ignoring the potential for synergistic effects. Here we show that changes in temperature systematically alter the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. As temperatures depart from ambient conditions, the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning becomes steeper, meaning that more species are required to maintain ecosystem functioning under thermal stress. This key result was driven by two processes linked to variability in the thermal tolerance curves of taxa. Our results highlight that if biodiversity loss occurs independently of species’ thermal tolerance traits, then the additional impacts of environmental warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function. Our findings have important implications for the conservation and management of biodiversity and the functioning of ecosystems. © 2016, The Author(s).

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key region for navigation. It encodes the spatial layout of the environment and the direction of the animal’s head. The organization of these representations is not known. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record simultaneously from many neurons in the MEC of freely behaving mice. We found that grid cells, which encode the animal’s position, are anatomically segregated from border, head-direction, and object-vector cells. These data suggest that grid cells may form a distinct network. This organization may be important for the formation of the spatial map. It may also facilitate the formation of the grid cell network. Flowering is a complex process, which is regulated by a variety of environmental and internal signals. In this study, we show that the FT gene in the rootless parasitic plant Cuscuta australis is not required for flowering of the host plant. Instead, the FT protein is able to move from the host to the parasite, where it physically interacts with a dodder FD transcription factor to activate flowering of the parasite. This study demonstrates that FTs can function as an important interplant flowering signal in host–parasite interactions. The unique means of flowering regulation of dodder illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. This study also provides a model for understanding the evolution of flowering regulation in plants. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Parkinson’s disease is a disorder of the dopamine system. The precise nature of the pathophysiology of this disorder is not known. Here, we show that the dopamine system is organized in a highly complex manner. We describe a specialized system within the dopamine-containing nigral system that is affected in Parkinson’s disease. This system, termed the “striosome–dendron bouquet,” is a highly specialized integration unit within the dopamine-containing nigral system.

We are social creatures, and we seek connection. But how do we know when two people are connected? We show that the speed at which people respond to each other is a robust signal of connection. This signal is used by people to evaluate the quality of their connections, and by third-party listeners to evaluate the quality of the connection between two people. This finding has implications for how we design social technologies, and for how we understand the evolution of human communication.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. The SAN is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, which are responsible for heart rate regulation. The SAN is a highly coordinated system that integrates multiple signals from the heart surface and internal stores of intracellular Ca2+ to regulate heart rate. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a key regulator of Ca2+ signaling in the SAN. Cardiac-specific deletion of STIM1 in mice resulted in depletion of sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR) Ca2+ stores of SAN cells and led to SAN dysfunction, as was evident by a reduction in heart rate, sinus arrest, and an exaggerated autonomic response to cholinergic signaling. These studies reveal that STIM1 is a multifunctional regulator of Ca2+ dynamics in SAN cells that links SR Ca2+ store content with electrical events occurring in the plasma membrane, thereby contributing to automaticity of the SAN. This study provides insights into the mechanisms of SAN function and may lead to the development of new therapies for heart failure. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. However, its function in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well characterized. Here, we show that Si pretreatment of rice plants enhanced resistance against the rice leaffolder, a key insect pest, in wild-type plants but not in RNAi lines that were silenced for the jasmonate (JA) biosynthesis enzyme allene oxide synthase (OsAOS) and the JA perception enzyme CORONATINE INSENSITIVE1 (OsCOI1). This interaction between Si and JA was associated with reduced Si cell expansion and reduced accumulation of Si in the leaves of OsAOS and OsCOI1 RNAi plants after insect attack. These results suggest that Si priming of JA-mediated defense responses and promotion of Si accumulation by JA may be a key mechanism for Si-enhanced resistance against insect herbivores. This study provides insights into the mechanism of Si-enhanced resistance against insect herbivores. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is still unclear. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is an important enzyme in the metabolism of ether lipids. We demonstrate that the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase is important for the activation of macrophages and that it is essential for the expression of proinflammatory and antiinflammatory cytokines. Our results reveal a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism of murine macrophages and reveal that alteration of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids.

Language processing is a complex task that involves the integration of information over time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory in the brain that is based on changes in the excitability of single neurons. We show that changes in the strength of synaptic connections can support memory, but that changes in the intrinsic excitability of neurons are necessary for memory on timescales ranging from milliseconds to seconds. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it is suitable for the binding of linguistic features over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a critical step in the development of plant biotechnology. Here, we demonstrate the delivery of siRNAs to plants using DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructures are important design parameters for the delivery of siRNAs to plants. We also show that the delivery of siRNAs to plants is dependent on the endogenous gene silencing pathway. Our work establishes the feasibility of DNA nanostructures for the delivery of biomolecules to plants and also details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work opens up a new avenue for the delivery of biomolecules to plants and may lead to the development of plant biotechnology. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Nutrient loading from small tributaries of large water bodies is often overlooked, despite their ubiquity and potential importance. We show that the 6 largest tributaries of Lake Michigan accounted for ∼70% of the daily nitrogen and phosphorus delivered to the lake. However, small tributaries exhibited nutrient loads that were high for their size and biased toward dissolved inorganic forms. Higher bioavailability of nutrients from small watersheds suggests greater potential to fuel algal blooms in coastal areas. Our findings reveal an underappreciated role that small streams may play in driving coastal eutrophication in large water bodies. Although they represent only a modest proportion of lake-wide loads, expanding nutrient management efforts to address smaller watersheds could reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient loading on valuable nearshore ecosystems.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is only available to rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the behavior of a mechanical system driven by a random force. We discuss the implications of our results for the study of chemical networks in thermodynamic environments.

We show that NMDA-receptor antibodies (NMDAR-Abs) can cause paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in patients. We use a mouse model of NMDAR-Ab encephalitis to show that the same changes in synaptic parameters that are tolerated in the in silico model of the control condition can lead to paroxysms when the same parameter fluctuations are allowed in the model of the disease condition. This suggests that the same circuit mechanisms are at play in both the control and disease conditions. These findings offer mechanistic insights into circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Ab. They also suggest that the same treatment that is effective in the mouse model may be effective in patients. This may be a promising avenue for future research. The Earth system is currently experiencing a rapid climate change. Understanding the history of abrupt climate change in the past is critical for understanding the potential for future abrupt climate change. Here, we present a case study of an abrupt climate change event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that this event was linked to a global warming and anoxia of the deep ocean. This event may have important implications for the future of the Earth system.

Certification of palm oil production is a key tool for reducing deforestation. However, the impact of certification on deforestation and fire in oil palm plantations has not been evaluated. We show that certification is associated with reduced deforestation in Indonesia. Nevertheless, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation.

The exocyst complex is a protein complex that regulates the last steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. The exocyst complex is essential for plant growth and development and is correlated with several significant diseases in humans. The molecular mechanism of the exocyst complex is not fully understood. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a fundamental process in biology, and the evolution of sex determination is a key topic in developmental biology. In this study, we investigate the effects of multiple interacting sex determination alleles on secondary sexual characteristics in a fish species with polygenic sex determination. We find that the modularity of secondary sexual characteristics produced by polygenic sex determination provides context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations. Our results suggest that the maintenance of sex determination alleles is not a simple matter of the number of sexes, but rather the number of sexes and the modularity of the secondary sexual characteristics produced by the alleles. This work provides a framework for understanding the evolution of secondary sexual characteristics and the maintenance of sex determination alleles in species with polygenic sex determination. The retina is a highly oxidative tissue that is challenged by the accumulation of reactive oxygen species- and light-generated adducts of vitamin A. The retina is also challenged by the accumulation of iron, which can be toxic to the cell. We show that the Fe chelator deferiprone reduces the oxidation and degradation of the bisretinoid A2E in the retina and in vitro. These findings suggest that Fe may be a key factor in the pathogenesis of age-related macular degeneration. This work provides insight into the role of Fe in the retina and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for this disease. (Read more)

Predator specialization is a key process in the evolution of food webs. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered a dead end, due to the constraints associated with the evolution of morphological and functional optimizations throughout the organism. Here we show that siphonophores, a group of pelagic predators, can evolve into generalists, and that specialists on one prey type have evolved into specialists on other prey types. Our results suggest that shifts between prey types are linked to shifts in the morphology, mode of evolution, and evolutionary correlations of tentilla and their nematocysts. These findings contribute to understanding how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs. They also provide a case study of how morphological changes can be localized in separate structures dedicated to prey capture.

The evolution of the human hand is a key topic in the study of human evolution. The fossil record for the evolution of the human hand is incomplete, however, and the earliest unambiguous evidence for key derived features of the modern human hand is lacking. Here we report the discovery of a hand fossil from East Africa that provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived feature of the human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process. This fossil suggests that the evolution of the human hand was more complex than previously thought.

Cancer is a disease of uncontrolled cell growth. One of the key metabolic changes in cancer is the diversion of one-carbon units from normal cell growth. This diversion is accomplished by the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT). SHMT is a promising target for cancer therapy. However, the development of SHMT inhibitors has been slow, in part because of the lack of a suitable chemical scaffold. Here we report the discovery of a small-molecule SHMT inhibitor. We also show that this inhibitor is effective in cancer cells, but paradoxically increases cytotoxicity in a subset of cancer cells. This finding suggests that targeting SHMT may be a promising strategy for cancer therapy.

Deforestation is a major driver of environmental change and is a key contributor to climate change. However, it is also a driver of food insecurity and malnutrition. This study shows that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets and dietary vitamin A adequacy. This study has important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals.

Mechanization has been a key factor in the success of modern agriculture. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We hypothesize that the roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants. Our findings have implications for the design of farm machinery and for the study of the impact of prehistoric animals on the environment. (Show more)
